title: Concentration of viruses from sewage using HA filters
title_html: Concentration of viruses from sewage using HA filters

protocol.title: Concentration of viruses from sewage using HA filters
protocol.title_html: Concentration of viruses from sewage using HA filters

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description: Take the sample out from the refrigerator.

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description: Homogenize the sample thoroughly, avoiding foaming.

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description:
Use a pipette controller, transfer 25 mL of the sample into a 50-mL tube (where MgCl2 has been previously added
). Repeat for each replicate. Save the rest of sample at 4ºC for archive or until decontamination and disposal.

source.title: final concentration
Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description:
Spike in each replicate 5 µL of Bovine Coronavirus recovery control (~100,000 cp/uL), prepared as
Bovine coronavirus solution prepared according to
http://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.bpg8mjzw

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description: Put the 50-mL tubes on ice until further processing.

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description: Filter the samples in the 50-mL tubes:

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description: Rinse the clean filtration funnel with sterile deionized water.

source.body: Make sure some water is still on the porous plate.

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description:
Place the HA filter in the filtration funnel.
filter

source.name: Cellulose esters filters 0.8 µm 47 mm diameter

source.body: Make sure the filter gets wet due to the residual water on the porous plate.

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description: Homogenize the sample in the 50-mL tube. Avoid as much as possible the liquid to touch the lid.

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description: Filter the content in the 50-mL tube through a 0.80 µm 47mm cellulose ester filter at low vacuum pressure (~50 mmHg VAC).

source.name: Gast DOA-P704-AA
source.type: High-Capacity Vacuum Pump, with Gauge, Regulator, and Relief

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description: As soon as the filtration is complete, transfer the filter to a 2-mL ZR BashingBead Lysis Tubes containing 650 µL of PM1 buffer solution (previously added).

source.body: It is important not to “over-dry” the filter on the filtration system.
Fold the filter as shown in Figure 1. Do not crease the filters with the forceps.

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description: Put the 2-mL tubes on ice until further processing.

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description: Repeat Steps 6 for the other replicates.

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description: Store filters at -20ºC until all samples are processed

source.title: Filtration of the sewage samples (in the biosafety cabinet)

source.description:
Store filters at -80ºC for a minimum of 2h or overnight prior to the nucleic acid extraction.
Archive filters at -80ºC.
